Award.AwardTitle: NUE: Introducing Nanotechnology into the Thermal and Fluids Curricula:

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Nanotechnology Undergraduate Education (NUE) in Engineering program entitled, "NUE: Introducing Nanotechnology into the Thermal and Fluids Curricula: A Multi-Department, Modular Laboratory", at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute (RPI) under the direction of Dr. Diana A. Borca-Tasciuc, has as its goal to expose undergraduate students to nanoscale science and technology aspects relevant to thermal and fluids engineering via a formal class environment using an experiential-learning approach. Four experimental laboratory modules will be developed to be included in two existing courses within the Mechanical, Aerospace and Nuclear Engineering Department and the Chemical and Biological Engineering Department. These modules will be focused on visual demonstrations and hands-on activities focused around the study of heat transfer, fluid flow, and capillary properties of nanofluids. By introducing the experimental study of nanofluids into the undergraduate curriculum both missions of promoting teaching and learning while advancing discovery and understanding are accomplished.

The proposed project will affect approximately 250 undergraduate students annually, which represents 100% of the undergraduate student population in Chemical Engineering and Mechanical Engineering. Furthermore, since two of the proposed experiments employ direct visualization of the phenomena under study, they may also be used as a simple yet powerful demonstration of nanotechnology to a high school audience during "Design you future day" a workshop organized annually at RPI to encourage women to pursue engineering careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With support from this award, undergraduate students in Mechanical Engineering Department and Chemical Engineering Departments at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute are being exposed to aspects of nanoscale science and technology relevant to thermal and fluids engineering using an experiential-learning approach. The topics are incorporated in Thermal and Fluids Laboratory and Chemical Engineering Laboratory, mandatory classes in each department, through four new experimental laboratory modules. All modules investigate the properties of nanofluids: viscosity, capillary properties such as surface tension and contact angle, thermal conductivity and pool boiling and critical heat flux. Students taking Thermal and Fluids laboratory are allowed to select one of these four topics prior to the laboratory and design their own experiment using existing setups. The students gain background and fundamental knowledge by reading first a handout prepared for each module. Next, the students have to design and perform an experiment to investigate the effect of specific parameters that may influence the properties of interest. Examples of investigations carried out by students include the effect of particle concentration on thermal properties or the effect of mixing different fluids on capillary properties. Students taking Chemical Engineering Laboratory carried out pre-designed experiments. All students must write a technical report on the performed experiments were they analyze and discuss the data and compare experimental results with theoretical predictions or literature data, when available. One publication describing the educational boiling module has been accepted for publication in International Journal of Mechanical Engineering.


Student learning assessment was carried out via pre and post-tests and interviews. The results from pre-test and post-test data comparison show that the students gained statistically significant learning of the technical content. From the difficulties encountered by some students in answering specific post-test questions and from interview comments, material to be covered in more depth during lecture part of the course was identified. Moreover, the majority of
students suggested more lecture content on the theoretical background, and also a stand alone nanoscience course that should be offered earlier in the program to have more impact on their career interests. Overall, students were
interested in future real life applications and conducting independent projects,
as well as learning more about nanotechnology and nanofluids and their applications to other engineering domains
